fields.headline: Patrick Cornelius: Infinite Blue – review
fields.bodyText: When it comes to what you might call the postbop mainstream – often small-group, horn-led jazz that mingles bebop structures with discreet borrowings from other idioms – you sometimes have to pay attention to ensure you haven't heard the same thing somewhere before. This set led by acclaimed young New Yorker Patrick Cornelius, an alto saxophonist with a coolly rounded sound and fleetfooted delivery, has some such moments; but if the elegantly polyphonic themes don't always grab the attention, Cornelius's improvising certainly does, alongside that of pianist Frank Kimbrough and trumpeter Michael Rodriguez, with Whirlwind boss Michael Janisch's inimitable double-bass growl lurking beneath. Three successive mid-album episodes here – Janisch's dark, Charlie Hadenesque intro to the ballad Waiting, the same track's brass/reeds melody, and the headlong, bopping twister that follows it, Puzzler – sound like they should have been the first dozen minutes of the set, but Cornelius is also breathily affecting on the dreamy In the Quiet Moments, with Kimbrough sympathetically mirroring his patient eloquence. Cornelius is due in the UK on 12 October as part of Whirlwind's festival at Kings Place.
